prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. Find the remainder when $2 \times 12 \times 22 \times 32 \times \ldots \times 72 \times 82 \times 92$ is divided by $5$.
solution:
We use the property $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ implies $ac \equiv bc \pmod{m}$.

Since all numbers with the units digit of $2$ has a remainder of $2$ when divided by $5$ and we have $10$ numbers,  $$2 \times 12 \times 22 \times 32 \times \ldots \times 72 \times 82 \times 92 \equiv 2^{10} \equiv 1024 \equiv \boxed{4} \pmod{5}.$$
gpt_response:
To find the remainder when $2 \times 12 \times 22 \times 32 \times \ldots \times 72 \times 82 \times 92$ is divided by $5$, we can consider the residues of each factor when divided by $5$.

We know that $2\equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, $12\equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, $22\equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, $32\equiv 2 \pmod{5}$, and so on until $92\equiv 2 \pmod{5}$.

Thus, the product $2 \times 12 \times 22 \times 32 \times \ldots \times 72 \times 82 \times 92$ can be rewritten as $(2)^{10} \times (10)^{10}$, where $10$ is the multiplicative identity in modular arithmetic with respect to $5$.

Therefore, the remainder when this product is divided by $5$ is equal to the remainder when $2^{10} \times 10^{10}$ is divided by $5$. 

By the property of modular arithmetic, we know that $2^{10}\equiv 2^{2}\equiv 4 \pmod{5}$ and $10^{10}\equiv 0^{10}\equiv 0 \pmod{5}$. 

Hence, the product $2 \times 12 \times 22 \times 32 \times \ldots \times 72 \times 82 \times 92$ when divided by $5$ will have a remainder of $4 \times 0 \equiv \boxed{0}\pmod{5}$.

Therefore, the remainder when this product is divided by $5$ is equal to the remainder when $2^{10} \times 10^{10}$ is divided by $5$. 

By the property of modular arithmetic, we know that $2^{10}\equiv 2^{2}\equiv 4 \pmod{5}$ and $10^{10}\equiv 0^{10}\equiv 0 \pmod{5}$. 

Hence, the product $2 \times 12 \times 22 \times 32 \times \ldots \times 72 \times 82 \times 92$ when divided by $5$ will have a remainder of $4 \times 0 \equiv \boxed{0}\pmod{5}$.
